Problem:
Consider a complex function \( z(t) \) governed by the differential equation \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \), where \( \omega \) is a constant real number representing angular frequency. We examine the changes introduced by performing a Laplace transformation on \( z(t) \), denoted as \( \mathcal{L}\{z\}(s) \).

If at a time \( t_1 \) an intervention is applied wherein \( z(t) \) is multiplied by \( e^{at} \) (where \( a \) is a constant), will the transformed function \( \mathcal{L}\{z\}(s) \) at any \( s \) be dependent only on \( i\omega \) and not on \( a \)?
Explanation: The intervention inherently changes the evolution of \( z(t) \), and thus the corresponding Laplace transformation will involve terms dependent on both \( a \) and \( i\omega \). The multiplication by \( e^{at} \) before taking the transformation affects the coefficients and the nature of the exponential terms in \( \mathcal{L}\{z\}(s) \).
causal_map_prompt: You are an expert in causal reasoning. Given the following problem description and question, identify all relevant variables and describe their direct causal relationships.Your output should be a clear causal map in textual form, listing directed causal links as "A → B" (meaning A directly causes B).Avoid redundancy or duplicate links. List only distinct and meaningful causal relations. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Focus only on extracting the causal structure. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "A → B; C → D; ..."}.
causal_map: t → ω; t → a; ω → z; a → z; z → z_dot; ω → z_dot; a → z_dot; z_dot → ∫z; ∫z → ℒ{z}; s → ℒ{z}; ℒ{z} → ℒ{z}(s)
